channel.title: My newest IRC bot
channel.description:
I made this at the house with an IRCD that I downloaded lol...it's a whole lot like pircbot, but I did make it on my own, anyway, source and shit is uploaded.
I've quit with these and went to RS hacking again lol, so you can do what you want with this.
PS. You may need 7-Zip to extract this.
[url=http://www.mediafire.com/?znboyjhytho]JIrcBot[/url]

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Evil_:

port that the socket you made is listening for connections on.

ie, the DCC server

is HTTP p2p then? how about ftp?

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:26, topic:256328”]you cannot share files with ctcp without extending it.
you NEED ctcp to start dcc, so i disagree its an alternative as they dont do the same thing.

its like saying TCP is an alternative to IP

also i stand by what i said about p2p.

spreading files with an irc bot isnt that good, its not very differernt then spreading them with http, because they are both client-server structures
but both those methods are very different to bittorrent which is peer to peer.

let me put it this way, if you destory the http server or irc bot, the whole system is down. you only need to kill one thing to stop it.

with peer to peer in general and bittorrent in particular, there is no central thing you can destory which will destroy the whole network.[/quote]DCC is p2p, you send a CTCP to the person asking if you can send a file, sending the information for the socket and port that the socket you made is listening for connections on. Then if they accept, they will making a socket to connect to your listening socket, in which case you can close your listening socket and use the newly accepted socket.

Now that you have that socket, you start sending the bytes of the file for them to receive, and they’ll send back the total amount that they’ve received, so you can acknowledge that they completely received the file.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @The_Flames The_Flames
item.description:
@The_Flames wrote:

Looking good. Better than anything I made, for sure.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:26, topic:256328”]you cannot share files with ctcp without extending it.
you NEED ctcp to start dcc, so i disagree its an alternative as they dont do the same thing.

its like saying TCP is an alternative to IP

also i stand by what i said about p2p.

spreading files with an irc bot isnt that good, its not very differernt then spreading them with http, because they are both client-server structures
but both those methods are very different to bittorrent which is peer to peer.

let me put it this way, if you destory the http server or irc bot, the whole system is down. you only need to kill one thing to stop it.

with peer to peer in general and bittorrent in particular, there is no central thing you can destory which will destroy the whole network.[/quote]

CTCP is just a more common way to initiate the session, as Mopman said, it doesn’t actually need it.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

You don’t actually need to use CTCP (or be connected to an IRC server at all) to use dcc send, but that’s usually how the handshake is done.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

you cannot share files with ctcp without extending it.
you NEED ctcp to start dcc, so i disagree its an alternative as they dont do the same thing.

its like saying TCP is an alternative to IP

also i stand by what i said about p2p.

spreading files with an irc bot isnt that good, its not very differernt then spreading them with http, because they are both client-server structures
but both those methods are very different to bittorrent which is peer to peer.

let me put it this way, if you destory the http server or irc bot, the whole system is down. you only need to kill one thing to stop it.

with peer to peer in general and bittorrent in particular, there is no central thing you can destory which will destroy the whole network.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Cain_:

don’t you connect directly to your peer when transferring a file with DCC?

To initiate a DCC session the client must connect directly to the DCC server, though using CTCP to initiate the session is an alternate method which may also be used.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

No, Yakman is pretty much talking about what I’m talking about. DCC dosen’t really fit any of the characteristics that would make something “P2P”, except “users are sharing files between each other”.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @force force
item.description:
@force wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:22, topic:256328”]i disagree that DCC is p2p.

you have one server (the IRC bot) and many clients (people who want files)
one dude says !get [filename] or whatever the command is
and the IRC bot does /dcc send [filename]

all clients get their files from one place, and they dont share it with each other like in bittorrent.

therefore sending files with DCC is client-server[/quote]
That makes no sense.

its p2p.

Your talking about a IRCbot that takes commands. It is still p2p though cause the IRCbot is starting a dcc with the person who requested the file.

I think you should revise what you said.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

i disagree that DCC is p2p.

you have one server (the IRC bot) and many clients (people who want files)
one dude says !get [filename] or whatever the command is
and the IRC bot does /dcc send [filename]

all clients get their files from one place, and they dont share it with each other like in bittorrent.

therefore sending files with DCC is client-server

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

DCC is p2p, but chatting isn’t.

item.title: My newest IRC bot

item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

thats because the reply is sent to the server and back to the requesting client?

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Cain_”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=338581.msg2627936#msg2627936 date=1231927409]
If it was p2p, why would you need a server?

Furthermore, using a server to chat to a big group is way better. Instead of sending one message to the server (client-server), for p2p you’d have to send a message to everyone in the channel.
[/quote]

I THINK they were originally talking about file transfer on IRC, which is DCC (p2p) which is much better than client-server-client :P[/quote]

I was talking about DCC, and I was saying that its not p2p

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:17, topic:256328”][quote author=Cain_ link=topic=338581.msg2627945#msg2627945 date=1231930208]

If it was p2p, why would you need a server?

Furthermore, using a server to chat to a big group is way better. Instead of sending one message to the server (client-server), for p2p you’d have to send a message to everyone in the channel.

I THINK they were originally talking about file transfer on IRC, which is DCC (p2p) which is much better than client-server-client
[/quote]
I was talking about file transfer, I’m not sure if anyone else was.[/quote]

Oh I see, well in that case it is p2p. File transfer would slow down heavily if it goes via a server.

Read full topic

If it was p2p, why would you need a server?

Furthermore, using a server to chat to a big group is way better. Instead of sending one message to the server (client-server), for p2p you’d have to send a message to everyone in the channel.
[/quote]

I THINK they were originally talking about file transfer on IRC, which is DCC (p2p) which is much better than client-server-client :P[/quote]
I was talking about file transfer, I’m not sure if anyone else was.

Read full topic

item.title: My newest IRC bot
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Mopman:

No. It is client-server.[/quote][quote=“http://www.irchelp.org/irchelp/security/warez.html”]Unlike other peer-to-peer (P2P) file sharing protocols, IRC was never intended for widespread file trading, so it has no official, centralized list of files and no standard commands for trading files.

Looks like its P2P to me.

Read full topic

No. It is client-server.
